Content: It’s Official! The fourth cohort of FishStalkers is ... OVER?? ... Well, not really,  FishStalkers is has been consumed by Human-Augmented Analytics Group (HAAG). Our new title fitting our expanded set of projects and collaborations. This summer our HAAG researchers are 15 talented Online Computer Science Masters student across the United States ... AND THE GLOBE! These researchers have come from various analytical industries to share their talent with the Georgia Tech Community and beyond. We are inviting you to participate in our many exciting community events to learn what HAAG researcher are all about. We will be holding various seminars and symposiums to share our research and other industry skills.Please Join us in welcoming our  inaugural class of HAAG Georgia Tech Researchers!!! Benjamin Yu, Adam Thomas, Aiden Campbell, Anita Cheung, Ayush Parikh, Elan Grossman, Jacob Shimer, Kailey C., Kausar Patherya, Nikhil Kapila, Terry Junsoo Park, Thomas Orth, Jeanette Schofield, Thomas Deatherage, Charlie Clark🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎Comment below if you would like to be contacted for upcoming community events! Or Check us out on the web: https://lnkd.in/gD4jygBc🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎🌎

I want to highlight the work of the Tranformative Teaching and Learning Graduate Commitee lead by Dr. Bonnie Ferri. My involvement started with a conversation with Dr. Ferri regarding the state of the graduate student role and idea that I have for altering the framework in which we view graduate student and their contribution to the broader Georgia Tech Commitee. I was excited to learn that there is a whole team of professionals: Graduate Students, Faculty, and administrators working together on the TTL commitees to implement data-based to improve our graduate programs. One of these members, Director James Black, PhD (pictured below!) has been an encouraging advocate of  empowering our graduate students. In that spirit, I was proud to present my new idea for expanding the role of graduate students in fostering interdisciplinary collaborations to the commitee, The Human-Augmented Analytics Group (HAAG). It was wonderful to received feedback and incite on the launch of this idea and I even had a few faculty express working with us in the fall! Learn more here: https://lnkd.in/gD4jygBcI am very appreciative of the transformative teaching and learnings groups commitment to centering student voices in the pursuit of better support for the next generations of graduates students. I look forward to continuing to learn from these experienced advocates. 🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝

I am excited to announce my appointment to the Graduate Student Emerging Leaders Advisory Board. In this group, I will be invited to share advise with various leaders across campus seeking graduate student feedback. I am dedicated to serving the graduate students interests and perspectives with this appointment. I will be working Kurt Keppler, Luoluo Hong, PhD, MPH and the Student Engagement and Well-Being Leadership to learn about their initiatives to support students. I will share the insights I learn here! A special thanks to those who nominated me for this position!❤️ I will make the most of this opportunity to serve my graduate community in a greater capacity. 🐝 🐝 🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝🐝

I am ending this academic year watching so many amazing researchers and friends finally become (or soon to be) Doctorates: Roberta Shapiro, Mengshi Zhang, Paramita Chatterjee PhD, MBA , Ian Helfrich ❤️I am proud to see them going on to greater things and I hope you know that myself and your graduate communities will miss you all very much!!Our provost Steve McLaughlin is always a blast to around and a commited supporter of Georgia tech graduate students. So he seemed the perfect person to honor these great researchers with! we had one last T-party before the big  graduation ceremony 👩‍🎓I am proud to say we were joined by some talented (not yet graduating) PhD students Princess Pinamang, Carli Roush, Daamini Visaalaakshi. Together, we will do our best to carry the Georgia Tech torch left behind as scientists, mentors, teachers, leaders, and people. ❤️❤️❤️❤️A million congrats 🎉 to Georgia Techs Finest PhDs ❤️❤️❤️❤️

I am proud to announce my new role as OMSCS research coordinator and instructor starting this summer!! Over the last year, I have worked with some amazing OMSCS student Jasmine Tata and alumni Jeanette Schofield. The dedication and ability of these students has inspired me to foster a connection with Associate Director of Research OMSCS Nick Lytle, Ph.D. And Executive Director OMSCS David Joyner that has lead to me joining their team to create exciting research collaborations across campus. It was wonderful to meet them both at the OMSCS conference and I am thrilled to see that they share the same passion for indiscipary mentorship as me! I am looking forward to learning from them and developing impactful research experiences for OMSCS students. 🙌You can read more about my work with Jasmine here:https://lnkd.in/gMr-JrUV

I am Graduate instructor of the year for Biological Sciences!!! 🙌🙌🙌🙌🙌I want to thank my students in My Georgia Tech VIP Program Course for working hard and making this possible. In my book, a successful teacher learns as much from her students as her students learn from her. I truly feel this encapsulates my experience teaching my research course. I also want to thank the professors who have as mentors in my teaching development. Kate Williams Thank you for inviting me to the Tech to Teaching program and for being a amazing instructor. Ingeborg Schmidt-Krey and Lauren Barbeau Thank you for supporting my student researchers as Faculty mentors for the Women, Science, and Technology program. I am very lucky to have the trust of my students as I guide them in research AND the wisdom of those with great teaching experience to guide me ❤️

Women Scientists  are amazing!!!! Zoey (Li-Yen) Yang and I were proud to share our experience with the women in computational biology mentorship program with the Georgia Tech Graduate News letter. Lead by the amazing Postdoc Avery Davis Bell, PhD and Faculty Shina Caroline Lynn Kamerlin. Zoey and I speak about the how this program has positively impacted our graduate school experience and how other women in the Georgia tech community can start building their own community.Read more here: https://lnkd.in/ggJut28XSpecial Thanks to Sara Franc and Brittani Hill for their work in the development and promotion of this peice. I am always impressed by the work of their office. It’s truly a honor to work with you both.❤️We also want to thank the Lisa Redding and King Jordan from the Bioinformatics Department for your continual assistance and support of our program. As Bioinformatics PhDs,  Zoey and I are excited to support the professional and personal development of women and gender minorities in the bioinformatics program through this program 😊I will end with sharing this post of Zoey and I having a blast at the Graduate Gala with our fellow female scientist Daamini Visaalaakshi as a very important reminder to my academic community: Women 👏Scientists 👏Are 👏People👏It very important to me that we reinforce a complete and humanized picture of the female scientist in our programming. I am excited to connect with and serve our next Co-hort of women in computational biology. ❤️❤️

Last month, I was invited to speak with the Georgia Tech Online Computer Science Masters students. I have had the absolute pleasure of working with a few OMSCS students and alumni Jasmine Tata, Jeanette Schofield, Junsoo Park, and Thomas Bowlin who have and are completing innovative research in the McGrath lab. I am inspired by these talented student researchers and I definitely learn as much from them as they teach me. I see the OMSCS students as leaders in the Georgia Tech community as many of these students have extensive industry expertise. We have a lot to gain from extending collaboration with the OMSCS community.That is why I am proud to announce that I will be collaborating with Dr. David Joyner and Dr. Nick Lytle, Ph.D. this summer to expand research collaborations between skilled OMSCS professionals and the greater Georgia Tech community. I am very excited to tackle the challenges of online collaboration because I truly believe their is so much to gain in our science from expanding access to interdisciplinary research. If you are a graduate student, faculty, or other researcher interested in learning about what OMSCS students can contribute to your team. Please feel free to reach out so we can design a project with OMSCS students that meets your computational needs.

I FAILED at the 3MT prelims round for the 3RD TIME!!!!!!!!! … AND I will be back again next year! 😎Let me start by saying, this years competitors were very strong and I’m happy for the graduate students who made it to the next round. I think they deserved it. I’d like to use this experience to springboard a discussion about why good ideas fail.If you are lucky, you will be in a space where your new ideas are heard and the people around you will come beside you to see the idea through and advise you on how you can make this idea better. But most of the time you can’t expect this will happen. Here’s why:NEW IDEAS= CHANGEALOT OF PEOPLE = HATE CHANGEWhen you are not in the position of absolute power, you need leaders and peers to co-sign your idea. If your idea requires people to act differently from their default, you have lost some percentage of your potential supporters on the basis of change. It doesn’t matter how “good” your idea is.I say this to demonstrate that it is STATISTICALLY IGNORANT to kill your own idea just because one or a few people don’t care for it. So a few people thought my talk wasn’t their cup of tea ☕️ Who cares? 🤷🏻‍♀️It will be 3 different judges next year and You all better watch out because next year I am coming for the crown 👑 !😂 I share this clip of my failure so that YOU might be brave enough to fail too. None of it matters as long as you dust yourself off and keep going, you will get to where you want to be eventually.

Very Proud to have Jameson representing FishStalkers research group at the neuroscience research symposium 2024. Jameson is a absolute pleasure to work with and he always brings a unique perspective to our team. This semester Jameson lead a Journal club for the undergraduates and masters student in the McGrath lab which is a very important space for peer-to-peer research colaboration. I’m proud see how far Jameson has developed as a researcher and excited to see what he will do next. Way to go Jameson!!

The highlight of my week was participating in a campus video about the importance of freedom of expression on campus which is being championed by  Vice President Luoluo Hong, PhD, MPH . This was such a great excuse to get out of the lab and be a part of the institutes discussion on rights, responsibilities, and expression. I am glad this initiative took an intentional look at the graduate student perspective on this issue. Graduate students are in the unique position of having both having the expression regulated by their supervisors and regulating others expression (leading classrooms, and mentoring student researchers). To me, the most important aspect of freedom of expression is the freedom to skepticism. You cannot create anything new without the freedom to be skeptical about ideas and the current norms in society. I was raised an evironment which was afriad of skepticism. I was taught evolution isn’t real and that females should not be leaders. Now, I am female scientist in a evolution lab who leads a group of student researchers. Academia has given me the space to be skeptical about ideas and develop my own beliefs. I seek to provide this level of freedom to every student who is brave enough to allow me to lead them. My challenge is to other leaders at Georgia Tech that you would also protect our freedom of expression by accepting valid skepticism and listen to new ideas with the same credence you would give your own.

Thank you to everyone that joined us for the BioSci Townhall Meeting this Monday! We were glad to see a good turnout of graduate students representing their respective programs. Building from the goals discussed within this group, we will be forming a BioSci Graduate Student Association (BioSci GSA) to implement changes based on the findings of the townhall meeting and act as liaisons for the graduate students from their respective program. This is a great opportunity to serve your graduate community, develop leadership skills and learn how to implement collective change in a higher education setting. Please fill out the link to nominate yourself or a peer to serve as a representative for one of the five BioSci graduate programs (APPH, BINF, BIO, OSE, QBIOS). We encourage you to think about people in your community that would be advocates and nominate them for this opportunity.  BioSci GSA Self/Peer Nomination Form:https://lnkd.in/gNr6dK4W Additionally, if you have general comments, concerns, or feedback that you would like to see addressed, please feel free to share anonymously using the following link: https://lnkd.in/g4D6qtek Sincerely, Bree Shi and Princess Pinamang

I am proud to announce my third generation of fishstalker machine learning researchers. https://lnkd.in/gXfU3WNbWe are a interdisciplinary group of 7 undergraduate and 4 masters level researchers across the following majors: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, and Neuroscience. I am greatly greatful to all my mentees for everything they have taught me and for taking initiative in our group. This community would be nothing without their buy in and faith in me to lead them responsibly and ethically. I do my best everyday to meet that expectation. I want to take this time to highlight two very cool FishStalkers. I’ve had the absolute pleasure to work with.Jasmine Tata and Jeanette Schofield are our first OMSCS FishStalker researchers. Through their passion for research, we have greater invented systems for conducting remote researcher. This has added a ton of value to our program that we are able to on-board researchers from anywhere into our projects. The OMSCS program is very unique that it attracts experience students already working in industry. Jasmine Tata and Jeanette Schofield are already quite skilled in computer science and frankly there is so much I can learn from them as people and professionals 😊I am honored to announce this Tuesday at 8pm EST I was invited by Nick Lytle, Ph.D. to present my work at the OMSCS seminar! I am so excited to hear insights about my work from this talented community and to share opportunities expand my collaboration with OMSCS professionals. As always questions and comments are more than welcome! Happy spring break to those very few academics that partake! 😂😎😂

Happy National Womens day!  I am excited to announce that me and my good friend Zoey (Li-Yen) Yang will be leading the next cohort of the Women Computational Biology Mentorship program! We will be supported in this endeavor by two amazing female scientists Avery Davis Bell, PhD and Shina Caroline Lynn Kamerlin. Zoey and I are looking forward to learning as much as we can from these amazing women leaders!🧬👩🏾‍💻✍🏻👩🏻‍💻🦾👩🏽‍💻🦿👩🏼‍💻🧠👩🏿‍💻🫀I was thrilled to speak on the new on the new bioscience and recruitment panel to share about this mentorship opportunity that has brought me much personal growth and happiness 😎Zoey and I are looking forward to seeing the next generation of women scientists be amazing at Georgia Tech! As always comment section is open for discussion 😊

This week I had the honor to meet Georgia Tech next generation of Bio-scientists at our annual departmental recruitment event! It always cathartic to share my experiences with the new PhD students and help them to make the best of their experience at Tech. I wishing you all the best of luck in your graduate school endeavors and I can’t wait to see all the great things you will accomplish here at tech. Please know you are welcome to reach out to me anytime. I am always happy to share the tips and tricks of the trade 😎🔬🧬

We are back at it again: 😋 WACKY 😋  👨‍🔬 SCIENCE 👩‍🔬  🤖 FRIDAY 🤖 I am here with my collaborator and phenomenal friend Luke Foster. Luke is a Third year Chemistry PhD using the Western blots technique to illuminate the role of proteins in cancer drug efficacy. Together we are designing a tool to automate portions of the Western Blot technique.  Continue reading for how you can contribute to this project!Research Pool is an exciting new program I am piloting to bridge the gap between scientists, engineers and the data scientists. Each group will be lead by one subject expert just like Luke and a data scientist like myself! Learn more about Luke's group and sign up here ... https://lnkd.in/gXvnPwvTPhoto Credits to my new friend Ian Helfrich :)

Here I am up to my 🧬Wacky 🔬science Friday shenanigans with my good friend 𝙿𝚛𝚎𝚌𝚒𝚘𝚞𝚜 𝙲𝚑𝚞𝚔𝚠𝚞𝚋𝚎𝚖 a second year Biology PhD at Georgia Tech Research using his skill to study heart development. Precious is a passionate mentor and scientist so I am thrilled to announce he has decided to co-lead one of our new Research Pool Projects in his subject of expertise. Research Pool is an exciting new program I am piloting to bridge the gap between scientists, engineers and the data scientists. Each group will be lead by one subject expert just like Precious and a data scientist like myself! We are currently still accepting members click the link below to read more or sign up to participate.https://lnkd.in/gXvnPwvT

Hope you all are having a 🧬WaCkY 🧬SCIenCe 🧬 FRIDAY! I’ll be your host and (nearly) certified 🤯 MAD professor.🥸To my right, you will see the FishStalker 9000 which is in beta testing to help us spot more fish then ever before!! 🎣 Here I will spend copious hours developing our stereo vision technology which will help us understand the mating behavior of wacky little fishes and only rarely banging my head into the wall so I can pass out and steal a minute of sleep from my 🧙🧙THESIS OVERLORDS. 🧙🧙🤓Stay tuned for more wacky science fun with Bree!🤓

I am proud to serve as the Graduate representative for the Georgia Institute of Technology Women’s resource director search committee. As part of this process, there will be an opportunity for the larger Georgia tech community to meet with our finalist candidates. If you are a graduate or undergraduate student who would like to give your feedback on which candidate YOU think best meets the needs of our community please reach out and I will share the times/location of these meetings. Otherwise, for those of you who may have less time, I encourage you to vote in this poll for which qualities you think are more important for supporting women at Tech. Thank you for your help making Tech a great place for women! hashtag#georgiatech hashtag#graduate hashtag#highereducationleadership

Asmita Lagwankar has returned from her co-op at Cellarity to complete her last semester of her Bioinformatics Master Georgia Institute of Technology . This semester, she will be co-mentor by myself and Biology PhD Cait Sullivan. Asmita is always an absolute pleasure to work with and I am so excited to see her apply all her her new skills from her internship into our new single-cell analysis. I was always e greatful to asmita for trust me to be her mentor. She is my first master’s mentee I will have the pleasure of watching graduate very soon! This amazing student will be on the job market in just a few months! Please send any good Bioinformatics/ data science job leads in your network her way! 🧪🧬🧪🧬🧪🧬🧪🧬🧪🧬🧪🧬🧪🧬

Shout out to my second generation of research mentees Michael Ortega Jasmine Tata Jameson Pham ! These amazing student researchers are finishing out the semester strong sharing their semester’s work with their fellow researcher. I am so proud of my mentee team and their work not only in their research, but also to uphold a high standard of colaboration to sustain a positive and empowering research environment. I am always trying new techniques with my group and not everything work. They have stuck with it and I am lucky to have these young researchers carrying the torch as second generation FishStalkers. 😊 I learn so much from my student researcher every semester as I strive to be a better mentor and leader. Thank you again for your trust and vote of confidence!🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠To any undergraduates or masters student, we are currently looking for students to join our group. Please send me a message to inquire! If you are a mentor who is interested in my mentorship strategies, questions and messages are always welcome! 🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠🐠Looking forward to all we will accomplish together next year! Happy holidays everyone!

Wow! THEY 🎓 DID 🎓 IT!!!🎓 I could not be more proud of my FIRST generation of research mentees who will be GRADUATES! So we went down to the cafe to 🎉hashtag#CELEBRATE 🎉 RESEARCHERS who were brave enough to give me my first chance at teaching research. I have had th pleasure of directing their scientific talent into projects that bloomed into biological and computational resources that will help many young researchers. Let me tell you more about what these AMAZING Georgia Tech Graduates are up to next and how YOU can help them on their journey.Chinar Dankhara is a dedicated and talented computer science graduate with a great gift for teaching and managing others. He came to my group to develop our computer vision data analysis pipeline and work on our Yolo-Sort object detection. He lead a group of student researchers in my FishStalker VIP course and has since gone on to pursue his interest in Natural Language Processing algorithm develop through his many appointments in both industry and academic labs. He will be continuing in his Georgia Tech Graduate Studies as a Computer Science Masters student with a specialization in machine learning. If you work in a Georgia Tech NLP lab, that is looking for a CS masters student, or have some advice for a up and coming graduate student please reach out in the DMs or comments!!!Annelie Minor is a skilled and hard-working Pre-Med biology graduate who extremely considerate and kind in all her interactions with others. She joined our group to improve our cichlid behavior studies and was passion about innovating in our studies and experimental design. She mentored student researchers in biology design in my VIP research course. She since continued her practical understanding of medicine through shadowing at a local hospital. Annelie Minor is currently looking for opportunities to use her degree for biology research in the Atlanta area before transitioning to an MD program. If you are aware of any labs looking for a wonderful lab technician or any advise for Annie , please reach out to us in the DMs or in the comments!!William Hancock is a pre-med biologist with as brains to match the size of his hilarious and energetic personality! He has a passion for learning new computational skills and help broaden our research impact through his unique biological perspective on our computational methods. He led a biological group in my VIP course and similarly shadowed at a local hospital. After graduation, Will will be pursing his MD! If you are aware of any labs looking for a wonderful lab technician or any advise for Will , please reach out to us in the DMs or in the comments!!I am so glad to see all of these talented graduates passion about continuing their education. I have no doubt that these young researchers will have a great impact on their community as compassionate and dedicated people. I thank you all for everything I have learned as your mentor and look forward to seeing you accomplish your life goals😊

A big thank you to all the first year bioscience PhDs in the tools of science ethics course for allowing me to visit you last day of class to share my PhD experience! Dr. Ingeborg Schmidt-Krey and Dr. Shuyi Nie do such a good job of making the concept of biological ethics an engaging and resourceful experience for the first year PhD students in our school. I am glad to share this panel with Marina Haldopoulos. It’s was exciting to share our perspectives on the Tech to Teaching program and give insights on the PhD process. This is a hotly debated subject, but I think the first year of the PhD is the hardest. It’s always hard to find community in a new program and at the beginning it’s easy to feel like your never going to have the skills you need to make it through. So to any 1st years reading this, remember this is a long process and try to enjoy where you are at right now. I know it doesn’t seem like it right now, but you are going to find your place in the scientific community. Comment below YOUR hardest PhD year and any advise you have for the 1st years coming up behind us! 🥼🙀😊 wherever you are in your education journey, you got this! One step in front of the other and you’ll be there in no time 😊

I hope you all had a peaceful break with your loved ones.  This year, I am thankful for my amazing mother Julie Shi-Branch has been an exceptional teacher to young people in Florida since I was in middle school (Which might explain a little about my passions as a researcher). Since high school, I have visited her classroom bi-annually to teach her students math and science.  I found an old video of my very first time teaching in my mother's classroom and I combined it with a video I took of me sharing my research with students yesterday! Now, nearing the half-way mark on my PhD, I thought it would be fun to share this journey with all you! Speaking to a new generation is easily one of the highlights of each year for me. I am lucky to have my mother who has encouraged me, but when I was their age, I did not even know a scientist! This holiday season, I highly recommend pushing yourself to get out of the lab and communicate your science to someone new! You could be the first scientist they meet and you might be surprised what you can learn from them!❤️

Thrilled to announce the launch of Georgia Tech Bioscience Graduate Association with Leah Pennell and Nolan Barrett !! Our goal is to foster greater community through targeted conversations on graduate student priorities. Be on the look out for more from us on our first town hall!

I had an amazing experience serving on the Scientist Panel for Girls in engineering day!!🔭👩🏾‍🔬🧬👩🏻‍🔧🩻👩🏼‍💻🧪👩🏻‍⚕️💻👩🏽‍🏭📡👩🏻‍🚀🧰A Big Thank you to Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics, and Computing (CEISMC) hosting this event! We had the opportunity to talk with young female scientists at the high school and undergraduate level and share our experience with them. I am so excited that these student have the opportunity to engage with this material at such a young age and they are an inspiration to me in their love of mathematics and computer science. I would highly recommend looking into CEISMC to any young person passionate about STEM. As always feel free to comment or message with any questions on my experience! And to all the young female scientists out there: I’M ROUTING FOR YOU!! Happy Girls in Engineering Day!🔬🥼📈

Excited to be a part of the Georgia Tech Neuro Next launch event! I met a lot of scientist across campus working in innovative neuro science applications. Please reach out to learn more about how I am studying behavior in cichlids through neuroscience! 🐠🐡🧬🥼

I am honored to meet with NREL’s building energy research team as a part of their iniative to recruit a diverse research talent. I learned so much about the impact that building science has on our sustainability goals as a country and the challenges that need motivated researchers to solve. I was excited to see that the people managing building energy projects were encouraging of collaboration in interdisciplinary project and had some interesting ongoing applications to computer vision. I was particularly inspired by the work of Dr. Ardelia Clarke in using data science to critically examine what equity looks like in terms of building performance standards and policy. I am extremely greatful to the building science research team for inviting to here about their cutting-edge research projects! As always, Please feel to reach out to me by comment or direct message if you have any further questions on my experience at NREL.😊🎉

I am honor to be invited to speak with Georgia Tech's Bioinformatics Organization on their Graduate school panel. It's inspiring to see so many students interested in entering this emerging field early in their career. We had great conversations about courses and experiences that will help students figure out if they want to pursue bioinformatics for graduate education. Missed the panel? Feel free to reach out and continue the discussion with me here.

My mentees Michael Ortega and Jameson Pham presented at the GT & Spelman Climate Workshop conference today and I couldn't be prouder of their dedication as student researchers. Climate science is a critical topic, and it's incredibly impactful to see my mentee find meaningful connections to it through our work and share their finding with our broader research community. I'm grateful to be a part of your journey and I’m looking forward to continuing great research with you!

Celebrating a year of mentorship with my student research team! Reflecting on our goals and determining effective strategies has been key to creating a community that empowers student researchers to pursue their fascination with machine learning and social behavior. I've shared my reflections on my impact with mentorship in this article and hope that my struggles and triumphs will serve as inspiration for any new mentors. Big shout out to Sara Franc for her work on this piece and to The Whistle for sharing my experiences with their audience! Share with anyone considering becoming a mentor.https://lnkd.in/ePHy4kQ7

I had an exciting time representing the McGrath lab at the Bioinformatics orientation poster session! I would love extend a welcome to our new PhD and master students joining the Bioinformatics program. Looking forward to witnessing all the amazing accomplishments you'll achieve! Please feel free to reach out with any questions on our programs or the Georgia tech community! 😁😁🎉

Exciting news! I was recently featured in the Grad Buzznews letter to participate in the "SERIES: Transition to Grad School Like a Pro".  I'm thrilled to be able to pay it forward and offer some tips for new graduate students.  I want to thank Sara Franc for her work on this interview and I hope that the advice with be helpful to you! 🤗 😎💡  Check out the article for some insights that I hope may help you or someone you know navigate through the graduate school experience. 💡 https://lnkd.in/gYdCqqCN

👾👾Sadly, The summer is coming to an end. But, I wanted to take the time to recognize my summer student researchers who have been working on pose-estimation this summer: Michael Ortega, Jameson Pham, Parul Methi, and Harini Mudradi. I am headed into my second year serving as a research mentor and I truly cannot tell you how much I have grown through this experience. Working on a interdisciplinary team, provides you with so many new perspectives you wouldn’t otherwise be able to interact with. I can’t wait to see what we will accomplish in together this year. As always feel free to reach out if you have questions on my mentorship experience. 👾👾

Looking for something to do this summer? Interested in Bioinformatics or Machine Learning? I may have just the thing for you!Myself and my mentee group (FishStalkers) are proud to announce are our twice weekly remote journal clubs in Bioinformatics and Machine Learning summer journal clubs. We all had a blast teaching the Georgia Tech Research community at our Mathematics and Computer Science Symposium this spring and we want to keep those conversations going in our newest educational outreach program! These groups will be lead by myself and Veena G. a fantastic computer science student and Women, Science, and Technology fellow who is passionate about making machine learning and bioinformatics topics accessible to all researchers and learners. This opportunity is open to everyone in the Georgia Tech community😊 Looking forward to seeing you there!!Here is what you need to know: Machine Learning Journal Club: Mondays 5 - 6 PM ESTSource materials: https://lnkd.in/g-c_xaufJoin the teams chat: https://lnkd.in/eybtduAJBioinformatics Journal Club: Thursdays 5 - 6 PM ESTSource materials: https://lnkd.in/gAPAPV5CJoin the teams chat: https://lnkd.in/eTWn3mGj

Congratulations to my Biology undergraduate researcher for their phenomenal work presenting at the Undergraduate Research Symposium! Annelie Minor , Emma Volkmann, and William Hancock came together over the course of a semester to present their work on cross-species cichlid behavioral studies. Annelie Minor and William Hancock have been working with me since September 2022. I have really seen them grow as researchers over this time. In January, Emma join our team as a Fast-Track Scholar and she was diligent in her studies to learn the previous work in this project.  As Scientist, I feel it really doesn't matter what we do unless you can convey to others the impacts of our work. I am extremely proud of their efforts to share their research with the broader Georgia Tech Research community!I could not be happier with the work that they put in to this project and look forward to continuing our work this fall!

I would like to send out a huge congratulations to Harini Mudradi and Asmita Lagwankar on the completion of their first year of Bioinformatics MS. I have had the absolute pleasure of working with these two driven students and researchers since august 2022. They are members of my very first co-hort of mentees in PhD and I greatly appreciate them putting their faith in me to support their development as researchers. Harini Mudradi will be continuing her research in computational behavioral analysis here in the McGrath Lab this summer and graduating in Fall 2023. Asmita Lagwankar has accepted a  Computational Biology Co-op internship at Cellarity, Boston and will return to complete her masters spring 2024! It has been a great year working together and I can't wait to see what we will accomplish next!!

This semester I was celebrated with a display for Graduate Student appreciation week by nomination from my fantastic students researcher in my FishStalkers Georgia Tech VIP Program course. I was asked to chose a item which represent my collaboration, so my students help we made a colleague of our growth and experiences as mentorship group. I have been (and still on) a long journey to mentor my students well and to help them achieve personal success. I am appreciative of them putting their faith in me as their mentor and sticking with our group while I am learning to be an instructor, mentor, and advocate. 🐟 To all my FishStalkers out there, I hope you will consider this a symbol of all of our successes and hard-work this semester,  and further I thank you for your nomination. Know that I consider leadership a responsibility and not a privilege of my expertise, and I will continue to do my best to uphold and surpass your expectations for my role.  🐟 If you are interested in my mentorship system feel free to reach out! I am alway happy to help others learn from my experiences (and mistakes haha) 😂
